column1: Jaggayyapeta is a census town in Krishna district of the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. It is also the mandal headquarters of Jaggayyapeta mandal of Vijayawada revenue division. The town is located on the banks of the Paleru River which is a tributary of the Krishna River.
Jaggaiahpeta was governed by a ruler
column2: by name Sri Rajah Vasireddy Venkatadri Nayudu. It is said that he founded two towns

column1: Government records suggest the founder of the town was Venkatadri Nayudu
column2: who developed and renamed the village of Betavolu to Jaggayyapeta. The region was then infested with robbers and hence the old village was called Dongala Betavolu (Robbers' Betavolu). For some time
column3: Jaggayyapeta was mentioned in Government records with Betavolu written in brackets. This region has an ancient history
column6: has in it the remains of an ancient stupa
column7: which has been lying there for 2
column8: 000 years. Jaggayyapeta became a municipality in 1987 and Sreeram Badari Narayanarao was elected as 1st municipal chairman.

column1: The Archaeological excavation around the town of Jaggayyapeta has found Buddhist stupa of 200 BC. Many sculptures and scriptures of Neolithic
column2: Megalithic and medieval periods are also found around the town.

column1: Jaggayyapeta municipality was formed in the year 1988. It is a IIâ€“Grade Municipality with 23 wards and spread over an area of 23.50 km2 (9.07 sq mi).
The Mango orchards are in abundant with Banginapalli
column3: those are even exported to foreign countries. It is one of major industrial corridors in Krishna district.It has all the major cement plants in and around like

column2: which connects Pune and Machilipatnam. APSRTC operates buses from Jaggayyapeta bus station which also has a bus depot. The town has a total road length of 109.00 km (67.73 mi).
